overview_of_class: This course focuses on regression-like methods for categorical outcomes, notably binary outcomes, ordered outcomes, nominal outcomes, and event and count outcomes. If time permits, we may also discuss multi-level models and methods to improve causal inference from non-experimental data. A major assignment for the course will be for students to write a paper that is a data analysis of secondary data.
name: Statistical Analysis of Social Data: Applied Regression Methods II
title: WCAS SOCIOL 401-2-20 Statistical Analysis of Social Data: Applied Regression Methods II
enrl_requirement:
Enrollment Requirements: Sociology/MORS PhD Students

Students must have completed or be currently enrolled in SOCIOL 401-1 or have received the intstructors permission to register for this class.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course focuses on regression-like methods for categorical outcomes, notably binary outcomes, ordered outcomes, nominal outcomes, and event and count outcomes. If time permits, we may also discuss multi-level models and methods to improve causal inference from non-experimental data. A major assignment for the course will be for students to write a paper that is a data analysis of secondary data.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Sociology graduate students only. Students from other departments may enroll with instructor permission if space allows.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Required: J. Scott Long. 1997. Regression Models for Categorical and Limited Dependent Variables. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage.

Recommended: Alan C. Acock. 2015. A Gentle Introduction to Stata. 5th Edition. College Station, Texas: Stata Press.

Please confirm all books before purchasing.

subject: SOCIOL
